title: My Nephew Was Born at 9 AM Today
body: And I will always secretly think of him as little baby Pentadunk.

A FNC fan totally just downvoted a newborn baby. So salty.

An* FNC fan
:(
an is only used if the next word starts with a vowel. An example, An asshole. A FNC fan. See the difference?

> [{quoted}](name=Noski7,realm=NA,application-id=9hBQwnEU,discussion-id=HozoMUkX,comment-id=000800000000,timestamp=2015-10-04T19:59:26.431+0000)
>
> An asshole. A FNC fan. See the difference?

aren't they the same kappa
..not really.

Actually it is http://english.stackexchange.com/questions/152/when-should-i-use-a-vs-an
You're welcome.
you misunderstand, it kind of ruins it to explain, but I will anyway. You said " An asshole. A FNC fan. See the difference?" I then responded with "not really", implying FNC fans are assholes.

Oops.
https://memecrunch.com/image/524b90d31605fb5d6400004e.gif?w=320
No, it's used if the next _sound_ is a vowel sound. In this case, it's eff. Eff enn see. So an FNC is correct.
um FNC is fnatic right? its pronounced phhhhh natic theres no vowel sound,
FNC does stand for Fnatic, so "A Fnatic fan" is correct, but since the _acronym_ starts with a vowel sound, it is an FNC fan.

No, it's about the sound.  FNC is an acronym, and if it were spelled phonetically it would be Eff Enn See, so you say an not a.

Grammar Nazi, sorry I had to

>
> No, it's about the sound.  FNC is an acronym, and if it were spelled phonetically it would be Eff Enn See, so you say an not a.
> 
> Grammar Nazi, sorry I had to

Well actually FNC is an abbreviation alone. Because if you actually try to say FNC as a word you end up making a really weird sound and it doesn't sound like an English word at all. Just throwing that out there.
is mute h considered a vowel? I am sure it is correct an hour not a hour
if you spell out Fnatic then 'a', if you say "ef en si" then 'an'
